message.text:
@G[c3 stills_123.png]@L @H Message @L Governor, the birds flew over Capitoline Hill and settled on the roof of Jupiter Optimus Maximus, this is a sure sign from the gods. I have heard of your dedication to Mars and your struggle against the Carthaginian menace. Consider the decree to limit medical facilities relaxed in your city. They shall surely be needed to deal with the casualties of war. @L@L May Jupiter grant you strength, @L@L - Publius Licinius Crassus, Pontifex Maximus Romae @L@L @H Reward @L Clinics unlocked. @G[medic.png]
@H Historical Background @L Pontifex Maximus was the chief elected religious official in Rome and ruled over a college of pontiffs that interpreted omens and oversaw the Roman calendar, where days had to be manually assigned as holidays to keep the years even. @L@L This position was not mutually exclusive with offices on the Cursus Honorum, however, so even this posting became highly sought after as a political power tool. Public holidays or bad omens would disrupt Senate meetings whenever hostile agenda was being proposed. @L@L Later in his life, Julius Cesar would hold the position of Pontifex Maximus which would generally be held for life. He used it to invent the Julian calendar and fix the many issues with the old system, taking away the power of assigning holidays and disrupting the Senate with bad omens, and turning the position into a non-political religious posting. @L@L During Caesar's year as consul, his co-consul Bibulus held the position of Pontifex Maximus. Bibulus was a conservative and intended to veto any legislation proposed by Caesar. @L@L In an incident when a meeting went nowhere after proposing direly needed reforms and the opposition showing little or no support, Ceasar bypassed the Senate and proceeded to read the bill of the expanded grain dole to the public assembly, where citizens would hear out a law being proposed and raise their hands to show support or opposition. @L@L While Caesar was reading the bill, Bibulus and conservative tribunes of the plebs came to veto the proposal. Since the grain dole was to directly benefit the urban poor, a citizen mob descended on the senators and dumped manure on Bibulus' head. This shook the man to his core, and he refused to show up in public or in Senate meetings from that point on, leaving Caesar to pursue his agenda virtually unopposed. @L@L Since Bibulus was Pontifex Maximus, he declared bad omens constantly but after the incident he became a laughing stock of the Roman public and was just ignored. @L@L One reason for such staunch hatred from the conservative faction against Caesar was that he terrified the Senate. At some point, rich and influential senators Marcus Licinius Crassus and Pompey Magnus were at odds with each other and the Senate. Unable to push through their own agenda even though they had served the Republic, they decided to create the first triumvirate by having Caesar as an olive branch between themselves, throwing their political support behind him and funding his endeavours. @L@L When conservatives saw this, they were horrified that such a power block is now in control of the Assembly. Many conservatives such as Cato the Younger would oppose Caesar for life after the show he made of his power, which made a mockery of the institutions and established rule.@L@L This tension only highlighted the issues inherent in the Roman political system and civil wars would eventually follow, which led to rise of popular politicians inspired by Caesar's school of thought. Eventually, Rome was turned from a Republic into an Empire; many people think that the first emperor of Rome was Augustus who was an adoptive son of Julius Caesar, but he never held the title officially. One could certainly argue that he was an emperor in all but name, but the first official emperor was Tiberius. Augustus' full name was Augustus Julius Caesar after his adoptive father, and Tiberius was named Tiberius Julius Caesar Augustus, continuing the tradition of enshrining Caesar's name as sovereign. @L@L@L@L
